text: EMN-KCMD Migration Country Factsheets: Statistical annexes 2021 and How to Read Guide Belmonte, Martina Sermi, Francesco 2021

This publication is a Technical report by the Joint Research Centre (JRC), the European Commission’s science and knowledge service. It aims to provide evidence-based scientific support to the European policymaking process. The scientific output expressed does not imply a policy position of the European Commission. Neither the European Commission nor any person acting on behalf of the Commission is responsible for the use that might be made of this publication. For information on the methodology and quality underlying the data used in this publication for which the source is neither Eurostat nor other Commission services, users should contact the referenced source. The designations employed and the presentation of material on the maps do not imply the expression of any opinion whatsoever on the part of the European Union concerning the legal status of any country, territory, city or area or of its authorities, or concerning the delimitation of its frontiers or boundaries. Content These statistical annexes complement the 2020 EMN Country Factsheets , available at the following link: https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/what-we-do/networks/european_migration_network/reports/factsheets_en In this document, you will find the ‘How to read the statistical annex’ , explaining the data shown chart by chart, along with the data source, and the statistical annexes of Country Factsheets of the EU Member States plus Norway in alphabetical order (following the English spelling of the country).

First residence permits annually issued: total number and % of total population in the country (and EU) The bars show the number of first residence permits issued every year in the country for the last four years. The percentages on the top of each bar show the share of permits over the population both in the country and in the EU27 (in yellow). Please note that due to a later publication date by the source, data covers an earlier four-year period. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_resfir st&lang=en https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_pop 1ctz&lang=en Top 3 nationalities of number of first residence permits annually issued: number of permits and % of total annual permits The bars show the number of first residence permits issued annually to the top three nationalities, in absolute number and as a percentage of the total number of residence permits issued (to known nationalities) by the country in each year. Please note that due to a later publication date by the source, data covers an earlier four-year period. If more than one nationality occupies the fifth position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_resfi rst&lang=en First residence permits annually issued by reason The chart shows the types of first residence permits issued, by reason: Remunerated activities (‘Work’), Family, Education and Other. Link to data source http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/ nui/show.do?dataset=migr_resfirst&l ang=en EMN Country Factsheets How to read the statistical annex GENERAL NOTES These four pages describe each individual chart in the statistical annex. It also provides links to the data sources. The extraction date is 8 June 2021 for all sources. For any question, please contact EMN or KCMD. EMN Country Factsheets are available here. For comparability purposes in future years EU values are calculated on the basis of the EU-27 Member States, following Eurostat’s aggregate ‘EU27 countries (from 2020)’. LEGAL MIGRATION AND MOBILITY COLOR LEGEND This colour/symbol code is used throughout the annex. Third-Country Nationals as % of total population (in the country and in the EU) The bars show the number of people residing in the country who have the citizenship of neither the reporting country or any other EU- 27 Member States, or the UK. This is shown as an absolute number (right-hand side) and as a share of the total population (within the bars). Data covers the last four years. The yellow percentages indicate the share of Third-Country Nationals over the total population in the EU-27. Link to data source : https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_pop1ctz&lang=en First residence permits annually issued for work reasons The chart shows the sub-types of first residence permits issued for ‘Work’. The categories are: highly skilled workers, researchers, EU Blue Cards, seasonal workers and other. Only the ones for which permits are issued are shown. Link to data source https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/sho w.do?dataset=migr_resocc&lang=en First residence permits annually issued for ‘other’ reasons The chart shows the sub-types of first residence permits issued for ‘Other reasons’. The categories are: refugee and subsidiary protection, humanitarian reasons, residence only, unaccompanied minors, victims of trafficking in human beings, and other. Only the ones for which permits are issued are shown. Link to data source https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?d ataset=migr_resoth&lang=en

Top 3 nationalities of annual number of first instance decisions: number of decisions (% of total decisions in the country) and % of positive outcome The chart shows the three nationalities with the highest number of asylum decisions in the country, each year for the last four years (rounded data). The number of decisions taken for each nationality are reported on the right of the bar. This is shown as an absolute number and as a share of the total number of decisions taken in the country in the year. The outcome of the decision (positive or negative) is indicated by the colours and by the percentages in the relevant part of the bars (positive decisions only). If more than one nationality occupies the third position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_asy dcfsta&lang=en INTERNATIONAL PROTECTION INCLUDING ASYLUM Top 3 nationalities of annual number of first-time asylum applications: number of applications and % of total annual applications The chart shows the top three nationalities of people who have lodged applications for asylum in the country (rounded data). The top three nationalities are sorted top-down by decreasing number of first-time asylum applications. The number of annual applications per nationality and the share of these over the total annual applications in the Member State are shown. If more than one nationality occupies the third position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_a syappctza&lang=en Total and first time asylum applications; first time asylum applications as a % of the population in the country (and in EU) The grey and blue bars show respectively the annual number of total and first-time asylum applications in the country for the last four years (rounded data). The percentages below the bars show the share of first time asylum applications over the population both in the country and in the EU27 (in yellow). Link to data source: https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_as yappctza&lang=en https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_po p1ctz&lang=en Number of first instance asylum decisions by outcome (% of total decisions) The chart shows the number (and share) of first-instance decisions on asylum applications in the Member State by outcome (rounded data). It shows this for the last four years. It also shows the total number of decisions taken (right side of the bar). The possible outcomes are: ‘Geneva convention status’ (blue); ‘Subsidiary protection’ (light blue); ‘Humanitarian protection’ (cyan); and ‘Rejected application’ (grey). If an outcome is not available in the Member State or no decisions have resulted in that outcome, this is not displayed in the legend. Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_asydcfsta&lang=en Third-Country Nationals resettled: absolute number and as % total resettled in EU The chart shows the number of Third-Country Nationals resettled to the country each year over the last four years (rounded data). The percentages report the share of Third-Country Nationals resettled over the total number of those resettled to the EU-27. Link to data source https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_as yresa&lang=en

Stateless, Recognised Non-Citizens (RNC) and Unknown Citizens The chart shows the number of people usually residing in the country and i) who are not considered as nationals by any State under the operation of its law (‘Stateless’ in blue); ii) who are not citizens of the reporting country nor of any other country, but who have established links to that country which include some but not all rights and obligations of full citizenship (‘Recognised Non-Citizens’ in light- blue); or iii) whose citizenship is unknown (‘Unknown citizens’ in dark blue); in a given year over the last four years. Link to data source : https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_ pop1ctz&lang=en Third-Country Nationals who have acquired citizenship as a share of total Third-Country Nationals (TNCs) (in the country and in the EU) and in absolute number The chart shows the number of TCNs who have acquired the citizenship of the country in absolute number (right) and as a share of the total number TCNs resident in the country at the end of the year. The yellow marker indicates the share of TCNs who have acquired citizenship in the EU the same year. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_acq&la ng=en;http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_a cqs&lang=en The chart is divided into three subtopics, each described by two indicators. The value of the indicator [as %] is given for ‘Nationals’ (i.e. citizens of the Member State) and Third-Country Nationals – ‘TCNs’, i.e. citizens of non-EU27 countries nor reporting country. The yellow marker shows the value of the same indicator for the EU27. All values are relative to the last year available for both the EU and Member States. Social inclusion Persons at risk of poverty or social exclusion (18+) shows the percentage of adults who are either at risk of poverty, face serious material deprivation or live in a household defined as having a ‘very low work intensity’. Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=ilc_peps05&lang=en Overcrowding rate (18+) shows the percentage of adults who live in a household defined as ‘overcrowded’. Link to data source: http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=ilc_lvho15&lang=en Education Early school leavers (18-24) shows the proportion of people aged between 18 and 24 which has completed no more than lower secondary education and is not involved in further education or training. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=edat_lfse_01&lang=en Neither Employed nor in Education or Training (18-24) shows the proportion of people aged between 18 and 24 who are Neither Employed nor in Education or Training in the four weeks preceding the survey. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=edat_lfse_23&lang=en Labour market Employment rate (15-64) shows the percentage of the total working-age population which is employed. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=lfsa_ergan&lang=en Unemployment rate (15-64) indicates the percentage of unemployed people in the labour force. It is calculated as the ratio between the unemployed population over the sum of employed and unemployed population within the same group. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=lfsa_urgan&lang=en Unaccompanied minors applying for asylum in the country (and % of total applications from unaccompanied minors in EU) The bars show the number of unaccompanied minors applying for asylum for the past four years in the country, as an absolute number (rounded) and as a share of the total number of unaccompanied minors applying for asylum in all EU-27 Member States. Please note that not all unaccompanied minors apply for asylum. Link to data source: https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_asyunaa&lang=en; https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_asyappctza&lang=en Unaccompanied minors as % of first asylum applications (in the country and in EU) The bars show the share of asylum applications lodged by unaccompanied minors over the total number of asylum applications lodged in the country during the same year (based on rounded data). The yellow marker shows which is the share for the EU27. Data source on the left. UNACCOMPANIED MINORS CITIZENSHIP AND STATELESSNESS Top 3 nationalities by number of citizenship acquisition in 2018: absolute number and % of total acquisitions in the country The chart shows the top three nationalities groups of people who acquired citizenship in 2018. It shows this as an absolute number and as a share of the total number of citizenship acquisitions. If more than one nationality occupies the fifth position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_acq&lang=en INTEGRATION

Number of residence permits issued to victims of Trafficking in Human Beings The chart shows the number of residence permits issued to victims of Trafficking in Human Beings for the last four years. Please note that due to a later publication date by the source, data covers an earlier four-year period. Link to data source: https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?da taset=migr_resoth&lang=en Short stay Visas issued (% of Schengen) The chart shows the number of short stay visas annually issued in the Member State’s consulates around the world for the last four years. For Schengen countries, short stay visas include uniform visas (entitling the holder to stay in the territories of all Member States for a period of maximum 90 days within 180 days and that may be issued for a single entry or multiple entries (MEVs)), visas with limited territorial validity (LTVs) , and airport transit visa (ATVs). The percentage on top of each column represents the share of these visas issued over the total number of issued visas in consulates of the EU Member States that are part of the Schengen area. Please note that the Member State whose consulate receives the visa application may be different from the Member State of main destination. Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus and Romania do not yet issue uniform Schengen visas. For these Member States, the figures refer to national short-stay visas. Link to data source : https://ec.europa.eu/home-affairs/what-we- do/policies/borders-and-visas/visa-policy_en BORDERS, SCHENGEN AND VISAS Uniform Visas issued in top 3 consulate countries (% of total applications) The chart shows the number of visa applications in the three consulate countries with the largest total number of issued visas. It shows this as an absolute number and as a share of total visas issued by the consulates of the Member State. Please note that the consulate country might not be the same as the country of citizenship of the visa applicant, as this information is not available at the EU level. If more than one nationality occupies the third position, only one is displayed (following an inverse alphabetical order). Link to data source : https://ec.europa.eu/home- affairs/what- we-do/policies/borders-and-visas/visa- policy_en IRREGULAR MIGRATION The chart gives an overview of the trend for the last four years regarding the following parameters commonly related to ‘irregular migration’. All data are rounded:  Refused entry at the external borders – Third-Country Nationals formally refused permission to enter the territory of a country during controls at its external borders (including airports, harbours and borderlines). Link to data source : https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eirfs&lang=en  Founded to be illegally present – Third-Country Nationals who are detected by a country's authorities and have been determined to be illegally present (people who have been found to have entered illegally as well as to those who may have entered legally but remained on an illegal basis, i.e. overstaying their permission to remain) under national laws relating to immigration. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eipre&lang=en  Ordered to leave the country (OTL) – Third-Country Nationals who are subject to an administrative or judicial decision or act stating that their stay is illegal and imposing an obligation to leave the territory of the country. At the bottom, the chart on the left shows the top 3 nationalities ordered to leave – in absolute number and as a share of all nationalities ordered to leave in the country. Link to data source : http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eiord&lang=en  Returned to a third country following an OTL – Third-Country Nationals who have left the territory of the Member State, following an administrative or judicial decision or act stating that their stay is illegal and imposing an obligation to leave the territory. At the bottom, the chart on the right shows the top 3 nationalities returned to a third country after an order to leave was issued – in absolute number and as a share of all nationalities ordered to leave in the country. Link to data source : https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eirtn&lang=en RETURN AND READMISSION TRAFFICKING OF HUMAN BEING Number of Third-Country Nationals who left the territory by type of return The chart shows the number (rounded) of Third Country Nationals who left the territory following an order to leave (OTL) by type of return (in percentage): enforced (blue), voluntary (cyan) and other types (dark blue), which refer refers to the situation in which it can be reasonably presumed that the third country national returned based on some assumptions. The total number of total annual returns is on the right. Link to data source: https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=migr_eirt_vol&lang =en

Austria - 2020 Publication date: June 2021 GENERAL NOTES This four-page statistical annex complements the Country Factsheet with relevant migration-related data organised in up to nine thematic sections - depending on data availability. The dashboard-like layout of the annex allows comparability across countries as well as simultaneous visualisation of different indicators. Whenever data are not available, the relative chart is left blank or indicated with 'N/A'. Data are provided for the latest available year or the latest available four-year period. For some indicators, data are rounded in the source. The sum of percentages or of individual values might not add up to 100 or to the total value. This is due to rounding and confidence intervals in the original data. A How to Read guide, describing each chart and reporting the sources, is available on the EMN website. Belgium - 2020 Publication date: June 2021 GENERAL NOTES This four-page statistical annex complements the Country Factsheet with relevant migration-related data organised in up to nine thematic sections - depending on data availability. The dashboard-like layout of the annex allows comparability across countries as well as simultaneous visualisation of different indicators. Whenever data are not available, the relative chart is left blank or indicated with 'N/A'. Data are provided for the latest available year or the latest available four-year period. For some indicators, data are rounded in the source. The sum of percentages or of individual values might not add up to 100 or to the total value. Spain - 2020 Publication date: June 2021 GENERAL NOTES This four-page statistical annex complements the Country Factsheet with relevant migration-related data organised in up to nine thematic sections - depending on data availability. The dashboard-like layout of the annex allows comparability across countries as well as simultaneous visualisation of different indicators. Slovakia - 2020 Publication date: June 2021 GENERAL NOTES This four-page statistical annex complements the Country Factsheet with relevant migration-related data organised in up to nine thematic sections - depending on data availability. The dashboard-like layout of the annex allows comparability across countries as well as simultaneous visualisation of different indicators. Whenever data are not available, the relative chart is left blank or indicated with 'N/A'. Data are provided for the latest available year or the latest available four-year period. For some indicators, data are rounded in the source. The sum of percentages or of individual values might not add up to 100 or to the total value. This is due to rounding and confidence intervals in the original data. A How to Read guide, describing each chart and reporting the sources, is available on the EMN website. GETTING IN TOUCH WITH THE EU In person All over the European Union there are hundreds of Europe Direct information centres. You can find the address of the centre nearest you at: https://europa.eu/european-union/contact_en On the phone or by email Europe Direct is a service that answers your questions about the European Union. You can contact this service: - by freephone: 00 800 6 7 8 9 10 11 (certain operators may charge for these calls), - at the following standard number: +32 22999696, or - by electronic mail via: https://europa.eu/european-union/contact_en FINDING INFORMATION ABOUT THE EU Online Information about the European Union in all the official languages of the EU is available on the Europa website at: https://europa.eu/european-union/index_en EU publications You can download or order free and priced EU publications from EU Bookshop at: https://publications.europa.eu/en/publications. Multiple copies of free publications may be obtained by contacting Europe Direct or your local information centre (see https://europa.eu/european- union/contact_en).
